Award.AwardTitle: EAPSI: Pressure and Magnetic Field Effects on Certain Magnetic Crystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
There are materials whose electrical properties change substantially depending on external conditions such as temperature, magnetic field, and pressure. These materials can potentially be used to improve electronic functionalities and/or create new ones. One such functionality involves the utilization of the spin property of electrons instead of their charge property like most electronics do. Devices which take advantage of this functionality offer several improvements over their traditional counterparts including, but not limited to, reduction in power consumption and increase in speed. The magnetic crystal that will be studied exhibits properties that depend sensitively on the external conditions and has a very simple crystal structure which makes it an ideal model system for the study of more complex materials. This research will be conducted in collaboration with Dr. Cong Ren at the Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing. Dr. Ren's lab is equipped with the equipment needed to perform the desired resistance measurements: two cryogenic systems with different temperature and magnetic field capabilities as well as a high-pressure cell adaptable to these systems.

Europium hexaboride (EuB6) is the crystal that will be studied; recent Hall Effect measurements revealed a percolative phase transition in its macroscopic magnetotransport property. The Hall resistivity in the paramagnetic phase exhibits two distinct linear regions with a transition point at a single critical magnetization over a broad temperature range, which was interpreted as the percolation point for the more conducting phase. This project focuses on the further understanding of this phenomenon by performing magnetotransport measurements on EuB6 under high pressure. Hydrostatic pressure is known to substantially modify the magnetic state of EuB6; this project aims to examine whether the close correlation between magnetotransport and magnetization observed in ambient pressure persists to high pressure. This NSF EAPSI award is funded in collaboration with the Chinese Ministry of Science and Technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Measurements were taken in order to determine how the motion of electrons within the material being studied changed when subjected to different external stimuli. Specifically, the stimuli being systematically changed were the temperature, applied magnetic field, and the applied pressure. While previous work has been done combining any two of these three factors, these results are novel because they observed the combination of all three. Under ambient pressure, the density of moving electrons in the material had previously been found to have two different values which depended on the applied magnetic field. The switch between these two values was found to change at a distinct applied magnetic field that varied with the external temperature. Based on the correlation between the temperature and the magnetic field where the switch occurred, it was concluded that the switches were happening at a constant magnetization for all temperatures.

In this work, the density of moving electrons in a certain magnetic crystal was measured at different applied pressures. With increasing pressure, it became apparent that there were three values for the moving electron density instead of two. Once again the switches between each set of density values was found to change at a distinct magnetic field that varied with external temperature. Analysis was done on each switching point to see if it was occurring at a constant magnetization as was observed under ambient pressure.  It was determined that only one of the switches was occurring at a constant magnetization. Further, this constant magnetization increased with increasing applied pressure. While these results are exciting, they have generated new questions such as: What caused the third moving electron density to develop? Why does constant magnetization of the switch in moving electron density increase with increasing pressure? What can these results tell us about the nature of the interactions within the specific crystal being measured and how can they be extrapolated to other materials?

This work was performed by Chinese and American collaborators at the Institute of Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences in Beijing, China. Both groups were able to benefit from the exchange of ideas and information that occurred during and as a result of the project. These connections will be available for further collaboration in the future and will help the advancement of knowledge in condensed matter.
